Fig 1 Fig. 2 Spectrum of the Xenon lamp XE-300F. Fig 2 Fig. 3 CO (a) and H2 (b) formation rates and H2/CO ratio (c) in different reaction temperatures (300 °C, 350 °C, 400 °C, 450 °C, and 500 °C) and light irradiation intensities (0 W·cm−2. 2.75 W·cm−2, 3.72 W·cm−2 and 4.67 W·cm−2) with CH4: CO2: N2=1:1:2. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) The activation energy and contribution of light and heat to DRM reaction; (b) Maxwell-Boltzmann distribution and illustration of occupied percentage of “inactive, to-active, active” molecules. Fig 4 Fig. 5 Schematic diagram of molecular states of reactants under lower (a) and higher (b) reaction temperature in diffenert conditions (none lighting and heating, thermal and photo-thermal). Fig 5 Fig. 6 Activation energies of H2 (a) and CO (b) formation under dark and light reaction conditions in DRM reaction. Fig 6 Fig. 7 Formation rates of H2/CO (a) and H2/CO ratio under different light intensities (0 W·cm−2. 2.75 W·cm−2 and 3.72 W·cm−2) and different CH4/CO2 molar ratios (CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1: 2, CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.4: 2.4, and CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.8: 2.8) at 500 °C. Fig 7 Fig. 8 CO/H2 formation rates in different reaction temperatures (300 °C, 350 °C, 400 °C, 450 °C, and 500 °C) and light irradiation intensities (0 W·cm−2. 2.75 W·cm−2 and 3.72 W·cm−2) H2/CO under CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.8: 2.8 partial pressure (a, b) and under CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.4: 2.4 partial pressure (c, d). Fig 8 Fig. 9 Variation trends for activation energies of CO and H2 formation under different feed gases molar at dark conditions (a) and 3.72 W·cm−2 (b). Fig 9 Fig. 10 The two formation routes of CO in DRM reaction. Mechanism and kinetic characteristics of photo-thermal dry reforming of methane on Pt/mesoporous-TiO2 catalyst Zhen-Yu Zhang Resources Investigation Conceptualization Methodology Formal analysis Data curation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Project administration a Ting Li Methodology Investigation Writing – review & editing a Ji-Long Yao Formal analysis Investigation a Tao Xie Methodology Validation Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition a ⁎ Qi Xiao Data curation b a Institute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, Shaanxi 710049, PR China Institute of Industrial Catalysis School of Chemical Engineering and Technology Xi'an Jiaotong University Xi'an Shaanxi 710049 PR China aInstitute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, Shaanxi 710049, PR China b Science and Technology on Thermal Energy and Power Laboratory, Wuhan Second Ship Design and Research Institute, Wuhan 430205, PR China Science and Technology on Thermal Energy and Power Laboratory Wuhan Second Ship Design and Research Institute Wuhan 430205 PR China bScience and Technology on Thermal Energy and Power Laboratory, Wuhan Second Ship Design and Research Institute, Wuhan 430205, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Dry reforming of methane (DRM) reaction under photo-thermal catalysis route have attracted more and more attentions due to its fast reaction rate and higher conversion compared with traditional thermal catalysis techniques. However, most of current researches were mainly focused on the development of new photo-thermal catalysts, while the kinetic characteristics of DRM reaction under photo-thermal conditions was seldomly studied and discussed. Aiming this point, the performances of a Pt/mesoporous-TiO2 catalyst were investigated under different reaction conditions (reaction temperature, light irradiation intensity and molar ratio of feed gases) in this paper. It was found that (1) Increasing the light intensity and reaction temperature possessed a positive effect on the DRM reaction, increasing the formation rates of two products and H2/CO ratio; (2) The intensification ratio of formation rates of light/dark condition would decrease with higher reaction temperature; (3) Under dark conditions, increasing the partial pressure of CO2 was not conducive to the progress of the DRM reaction; (4) With light irradiation, an appropriate increase in the partial pressure of CO2 would be beneficial to the progress of the DRM reaction and improve the formation rates of the products. To explain the variations of light-enhanced intensification ratios and values at different temperatures, a possible simple model of light-enhanced reaction mechanism was proposed, and the contribution of light to the DRM reaction was deeply discussed. Meanwhile, combined with in situ DRIFTS characterization, the effects of operating conditions on specific micro-steps of the reaction were determined carefully. The obtained conclusions are of great practical significance for the design, development and process parameter optimization of photo-thermal DRM reaction process. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Pt/mesoporous-TiO2 catalyst Kinetic characteristics Dry reforming of methane Reaction mechanism Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Solar driven dry reforming of methane (DRM) reaction (Eq. (1)), in which two greenhouse gases (CH4/CO2) would be converted to produce syngas, is a promising scheme to release the always mentioned energy and environmental problems [1–4]. The produced syngas (CO and H2) could be used as a feedstock for Fischer-Tropsch synthesis to produce liquid alkanes [3,5] and synthesized methanol [6,7] which is the so-called solar fuel, realizing the green fuel production as well as the storage of spatiotemporal instable solar energy [8–10]. (1) C H 4 + C O 2 → 2 H 2 + 2 C O Δ H 0 = 247.3 kJ · mo l − 1 However, since the stability of the reactants, DRM reaction requires high temperature condition(>700 °C) to be driven [11–13], and it is critical to find suitable catalyst to overcome the reaction barrier. In the last few decades, servals catalysts for dry reforming of methane have been developed based on metals like Ni, Ru, Pt, Rh and so on [14–17]. Among them, Ni-based catalysts were widely concerned by researchers due to their low price, but their industrial application was limited since they would easily and rapidly cause coked to deactivation [18]. Noble-metal-based catalysts have stable catalytic performance so that they are worthy of consideration as catalysts for DRM reaction [19]. Although the use of catalyst promotes the DRM reaction and reduces the barrier of the reaction, the reaction temperature of DRM is still at a high scope (>600 °C) [20]. Even with concentrated solar energy to provide the required input energy without other additional heating modules, the high reaction temperature could also lead to the following problems: (1) Strict material and equipment requirements [21]; (2) More rapid catalyst coking and carbon deposition to deactivation [22]. Therefore, driving reactions under milder conditions is necessary for larger-scale applications. In recent years, the concept of photo-thermal synergetic catalysis has been proposed for kinds of chemical conversion processes. For example, Tang et al. [23] reported the metal-organic-framework based on a monolithic NF@ZnO/Au@ZIF-8 composite catalyst for CO2 reduction. The catalyst could achieve photo-thermal-magnetic field in the reaction system, leading to a drastically improved charge transfer and reaching high selectivity. Li et al. [24] proposed the ternary carbon nanospheres@TiO2/reduced TiO2 yolk-shell (YS) nanoreactor as a model solar water splitting system. The catalyst extended the light absorption range to the longer wavelength of even near-infrared light, reaching excellent photo-thermal conversion by the YS nanoreactor with a carbon core. The coupled photo-thermal catalysis significantly enhanced the H2 formation rate under sunlight irradiation (over 22 times compared with dark conditions). Peng et al. [25] used photo-thermal catalytic route to drive the ammonia synthesis reaction at atmospheric pressure. The prepared Ru-based catalyst can possess a NH3 yield of 3.5 mmol at 350 °C and 0.1 Mpa only with 1 sun irradiation. The above achievement showed the good technical advantages and application prospects of the photo-thermal catalytic route. In addition, the route could also be used in other reaction systems like reverse water gas shift (RWGS) reaction [26], CO oxidation [27] and so on [28,29]. Actually, photo-thermal synergetic catalysis has also promoted the DRM reaction. In this route, the power needed by DRM reaction is provided by thermal energy and high-energy photons (HEP), so that the conversions of feed gases (CH4 and CO2) and the formation rate of syngas are greatly improved [30,31]. For example, Pan et al. [32] prepared the MgO/Pt/Zn-CeO2 with high catalytic performance (CO and H2 formation rates were 516 and 356 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 at 600 °C under light irradiation), of which the increments were 3 and 9 times respectively compared with dark conditions. Xie et al. [15] prepared the Ni/TiO2 photo-thermal catalyst showing greatly enhancement of the formation rate of syngas by coupling photo-catalysis and thermal-catalysis into photo-thermal catalysis. By integrating the separation of excited e(-)/h(+) pairs in the semiconductor TiO2, the DRM reaction on the surface of the catalyst would be promoted. In our previous work [33], the developed Pt/mesoporous-TiO2 catalyst also showed considerable catalytic performance, of which the formation rates were 281.0 and 178.6 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 for CO and H2 respectively at 500 °C. In addition, the reaction mechanism of DRM reaction under photo-thermal catalysis was also explored to further clarify the reaction steps. Other researchers have also explored the photo-thermal synergistic catalyst, and the results demonstrated the technological advancement of photo-thermal catalysis over thermal catalysis [34] [35]. However, at present, the research on photo-thermal DRM reaction has mainly focused on the development of new efficient catalysts, or making an effort to elucidate the reaction mechanism under the photo-thermal co-work conditions. Although in these works, the catalytic performance would also be investigated as the evaluation index of the catalysts, the relationships of different operating conditions and reaction mechanisms were seldom discussed systematically. Actually, according to the results of the authors’ group, when operating conditions (reaction temperature, light intensity, molar ratio of inlet feed gases and proportional partial pressure) change, the micro reaction steps as well as the catalytic performance would also change. The kinetic characteristics are not only critical for evaluation of the performance of photo-thermal catalysts, but also of great importance for the improvement of the catalyst, as well as design and optimization of photo-thermal catalysis based new type of solar reactor. The vague understanding of the kinetic characteristics might also lead to the mismatch between selected operating conditions and the capability design of the catalyst, resulting in the performance loss of the chemical conversion. Based on the above reasons, it is necessary to further investigate the kinetic characteristics of photo-thermal catalytic DRM as well as the relationships between the micro mechanism and the operating conditions. Therefore, in this paper, the photo-thermal DRM catalytic performance of our previous reported Pt/mesoporous-TiO2 composite catalyst [33] would be evaluated experimentally in detail. The investigated working conditions include reaction temperature (300 °C, 350 °C, 400 °C, 450 °C, and 500 °C), light irradiation intensity (0 W·cm−2. 2.75 W·cm−2, 3.72 W·cm−2 and 4.67 W·cm−2), molar ratio of feed gases and the partial pressure of feed gas. Experimentally measured reaction rates and kinetic characteristics would combine with in-situ DRIFTS tests in our previous work [33] to elucidate the reaction procedures of photo-thermal catalytic DRM reaction under different working conditions. 2 Experimental methods Mesoporous-TiO2 was prepared by sol-gel method with tetrabutyl titanate (MACKLIN, AR) as titanium source and cationic surfactant cetyl trimethyl ammonium bromide (CTAB, SCR, AR) as template agent. Pt nanoparticle is loaded onto the prepared mesoporous TiO2 support by wet impregnation method with H2PtCl6 (SHANPU, AR). Detailed synthesis method can be found in the previous published work [33]. Schematic of catalyst evaluation apparatus was shown in Fig. 1 . In a typical process, 0.1 g catalyst and 0.1g quartz sand (40-60 mesh, Maclin) were mixed and loaded into a fix-bed reactor (15 mm × 8 mm × 1 mm), which were heated by a heating module and irradiated by a Xenon lamp (XE-300F, China). The spectrum of the Xenon lamp is shown in Fig. 2 . For the reactor, the middle cuboid area (15 mm × 8 mm × 1 mm) is the reaction region (filled the catalysts powder). The upper and lower parts connected with reaction region are quartz tube with an inner diameter of 8 mm and an outer diameter of 10 mm. The upper tube length is 175 mm and the lower tube length is 210 mm. The wall thickness in all areas is 1 mm. Before the testing of all reaction conditions begins, the loaded catalysts would be reduced by H2 flow with 80 mL·min−1 for 2 hours at 500 °C. During the DRM catalytic performance evaluation, the feed gases would flow into the fix-bed reactor with a different molar ratio (CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1: 2, CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.4: 2.4 and CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.8: 2.8) and a constant total flow of 80 mL·min−1. The outlet gases would flow into on-line gas chromatography to analyze the gases composition every 20 minutes. With the measured outlet gas compositions and the inlet flow rate, the formation rates of H2/CO could be calculated by following equations, (2) F out = F in , N 2 · Y in , N 2 Y out , N 2 (3) F out , H 2 = F out · Y out , H 2 (4) F out , CO = F out · Y out , CO (5) r H 2 = 60 · P r · F out , H 2 m cat · R · T out (6) r CO = 60 · P r · F out , CO m cat · R · T out Here, F is the gas flow rate (mL·min−1); Y is the molar ratio of specific species; Subscript in and out represent inlet and outlet. In addition, r represents the formation rate (mmol·gcat −1·h−1) of H2 or CO. m cat represents the mass (g) of loaded catalyst. Pr represents the reaction pressure (defined at 1 atm, 101325 Pa); T out represents room temperature (defined at 298.15 K) and R is gas constant. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Kinetic characteristics with reaction temperature and light intensity For general chemical reactions, reaction temperature is the main factor affecting the kinetic rate, extent and thermodynamic limit of the reaction. Fig. 3 (a, b, c) give the variations of CO/H2 formation rates and H2/CO ratio with different reaction temperatures and light irradiation intensities. The pressure kept 1 atm with CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1: 2. Obviously, H2 and CO formation rates increased with the rising of reation temperature, which basically obeyed Arrhenius law no matter whether or not light was irradiated on the catalyst. The figure also illustrated that when increasing the light intensity, the formation rates of H2 and CO would increase, showing a positive correlation. Comparing the increasing speeds of H2 and CO formation rates that were induced by temperature and light intensity, it could be found that reaction temperature has more significant impact than light intensity, which was determined by the different working mechanisms, and this would be discussed later. Fig. 3(c) shows the H2/CO ratio under different reaction conditions. Since no product formation was detected under dark conditions at 300 °C, the H2/CO ratio at 300 °C under dark conditions was defined as 0. Theoretically, if the reaction is DRM reaction only, the H2/CO ratio should be 1. However, the measured H2/CO ratio was lower than 1 under all testing conditions, which was caused by the happenning of side reaction (RWGS). RWGS reaction could convert CO2 and H2 into CO and H2O, comsuming H2 while producing more CO, so that brings down the H2/CO ratio. It should be noted that the rising of reaction temperature would lead to an increase in H2/CO ratio. This might be related to the thermodynamic properties of RWGS reaction [36], that is, RWGS reaction is more favorable at low temperatures, while DRM reaction is more favorable at high temperatures. 3.2 Analysis of the contributions of light irradiation on DRM reaction For the photo-thermal catalytic DRM reaction, a critical affecting parameter is light intensity. Fig. 3 has already shown that when imposing light irradiaction, the formation rates of H2 and CO would increase compared with the results of dark condition, indicating an enhanced catalytic performance for DRM. This performance enhancement could be observed under all the temperature conditions. The reason could be attributed to the photoelectric effect of the semiconductor catalyst under light conditions. When light was imposed, photo excited electrons and holes could be generated, separated and participated in the surface chemical reactions, working together with Pt nanoparticles to accelerate the DRM reaction. In the previously published work, several scholars [30,37,38] have reported the similar performance enhancement induced by light irradiation at a given reaction temperature. However, the focuses were mostly on constant temperature conditions, without discussing phenomenons under different temperatures. Comparing the intensification ratio of formation rates under different light intensities, it could be found that the intensification ratios are not the same. Therefore, the intensification ratios of the formation rates of H2 and CO were calculated and listed out (Table 1 ), which is defined as the ratio of the formation rate with light irradiation (2.75, 3.72, 4.67 W·cm−2) over the rate without light (0 W·cm−2) under certain temperatures (r light/r dark). According to the Table 1, the formation rate of CO would increase 0∼15.47 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 when imposing light irradiation compared to it without light at 350 °C. The increasing value would get higher when temperature increases (0∼33.76 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 for 400 °C, 0∼55.41 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 for 450 °C, 0∼73.31 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 for 500 °C). Therefore, with higher working temperature, the increasing value gets larger. The same variation trend could be also found for the formation of H2. Relative to the increase of formation rate with higher temperature, the light intensification effect would get weaker at higher working temperature. For example, the intensification ratios for CO formation rate (r CO, light/r CO, dark) at 350 °C changes from 1∼3.91, and this would decrease to 1∼1.51 when temperature rises to 500 °C. Similarly, the highest intensification ratio for H2 formation rate (r H2, light/r H2, dark) at 350 °C is 5.76, and this value would also decrease to 1.64 when temperature gets to 500 °C. To explain the weakened intensification effect of light irradiation at higher temperatures, a postulation is proposed, and the schematic is shown in Fig. 5. Assuming that the original activation energy under thermal condition is E a. Molecules with energy larger than E a are called “active” molecules; and in contrast, molecules with energy lower than E a are called “inactive”. When light was irradiated and absorbed by the catalyst, it could provide additional energy for molecules to overcome the reaction barrier. Therefore, when the case is photo-thermal catalysis, there are three kinds of molecules: molecules with energy larger than E a are called “active”; molecules which would have sufficient energy (larger than E a) after adding the incident photon energy are called “to-active”; and those molecules with energy lower than E a even if they absorb the photon energy would be called “inactive”. With the above definitions, the reaction process is illustrated in Fig. 5(a), meaning that the addition of light intensity would lift up the total energy level of the system, making more molecules to be activated, and therefore increasing the formation rates of products. Besides, according to the Maxwell-Boltzmann velocity distribution (Fig. 4 (b)), at low temperature conditions, the molecules are mostly located in the low-velocity region with lower energy; only a small part of the molecules would possess sufficient energy to overcome the reaction barrier (active molecules, A4 region). While after the absorption of incident light, the “to-active” molecules would get enough power to obtain the ability to fulfill the reaction (A2+A4 region). The relative proportion ((A2+A4)/A4) of “to-active” and “active” molecules would be larger when temperatures is lower since most of the molecules are located in the low-velocity region. However, in higher temperature conditions, the velocity distribution (energy distribution) of the molecules would change in which more molecules would possess higher velocity and kinetic energy. In this case, the number of “active” molecules increases significantly (exponentially growth according to Maxwell-Boltzmann velocity distribution). When imposing light irradiation, the “to-active” molecules would also increase. However, due to the characteristics of the velocity distribution curves, the relative proportion ((A1+A2+A3+A4)/(A3+A4)) of “to-active” and “active” molecules would get smaller compared with the lower temperature case((A2+A4)/A4). The above explanation is a simple but much more accessible description for the variations in intensification ratio under different working temperatures. Although this may not reflect the complicated synergistic effect of photo-thermal catalysis very well, using it to simply explain the variations of the formation rate seems reasonable. More intuitively, the schematic diagram of molecular states are shown as following. In Fig. 5, the three kinds of molecules were marked in different colors, and the its ratio can roughly reflect the trend of the above analysis. In addition, the activation energies for formation steps of H2 and CO were calculated by the Arrhenius formula and listed in Fig. 6 . For H2, the active energies are 113.9 kJ·mol−1 under dark conditions, 92.0 kJ·mol−1, 85.9 kJ·mol−1 and 80.2 kJ·mol−1 under 2.75 W·cm−2, 3.72 W·cm−2 and 4.67 W·cm−2 light intensities. For CO, the activation energies are 88.5 kJ·mol−1 under dark conditions, 70.7 kJ·mol−1, 66.8 kJ·mol−1 and 62.9 kJ·mol−1 under 2.75 W·cm−2, 3.72 W·cm−2, 4.67 W·cm−2 light intensities. Obviously, the apparent activation energies for CO and H2 formation would decrease with the increase of light intensity. The decrease of the activation energies also reflects the promotion effect of light irradiation on the DRM reaction. According to the values of apparent activation energy under different light intensity conditions, the linear fitted functions of activation energies for H2 and CO formation with light intensity is regressed as: (7) E a , H 2 = 113 . 3 − 7 . 299 I (8) E a , CO = 87 . 75 − 5 . 574 I E a is the activation energy (kJ·mol−1), and the superscript represent product species (CO and H2). I represent the light irradiation intensity (W·cm−2). 3.3 Impact of molar ratio of feed gases Molar ratio is another affecting factor that determines the chemical conversion process and catalytic performance of catalyst for DRM reaction. This topic has been discussed under thermal catalysis condition extensively, but seldomly investigated under photo-thermal catalytic condition. Therefore, to confirm the impact of feed gases molar ratio on the variations of intermediate and micro steps of the reaction, the photo-thermal catalytic performances have been measured at different feed gases molar ratios. During the tests, the total pressure was 1 atm, and molar ratios of CH4: CO2: N2 has three compositions, including CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1: 2, CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.4: 2.4, and CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.8: 2.8. The formation rates at 500 °C were shown in Fig. 7 , and formation rates with other reaction temperatures were listed in Fig. 3 and Fig. 8 . According to the results, in dark conditions, three molar ratios of feed gases showed almost the same formation rates of CO, which were 145.0 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 under CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1: 2, 140.0 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 under CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.4: 2.4, and 141.5 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 under CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.8: 2.8 respectively at 500 °C. Similar results were also obtained at other reaction temperatures, about 5.3 mmol·gcat −1·h−1, 4.6 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 and 4.9 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 for 350 °C, about 22.2 mmol·gcat −1·h−1, 21.2 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 and 20.6 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 for 400 °C, and about 65.1 mmol·gcat −1·h−1, 62.6 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 and 62.6 mmol·gcat −1·h−1 for 450 °C. With the formation rates of CO under different temperatures, the apparent activation energies of CO formation were calculated, and the results were 88.5 kJ·g−1·mol−1 under CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1: 2, 89.6 kJ·g−1·mol−1 under CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.4: 2.4, and 92.1 kJ·g−1·mol−1 under CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.8: 2.8 (Fig. 9 (a)). From thermodynamics, the activation energy is related to the participating species as well as the temperature condition, and would not be affected by the variation of molar ratio theoretically. However, the changing of apparent activation energy with molar ratio shown that different compositions of reactants would change the relative intensity of different micro steps, and therefore alter the apparent activation energy of the reaction. The almost constant CO formation rates under different molar ratios in dark condition were expained as follows: In DRM reaction, CO formation steps are considered the following two routes generally: (1) CO2 was directly adsorbed and dissociated to CO [32,39–41] (Route 1: step 6 in Fig. 10 ); (2) The adsorbed H species (from CH4 dissociation) and CO2 combined to form HCOO species and then decomposed to form CO [42–44] (Route 2: steps 5 and 7 in Fig. 10). For Route 1, the CO formation rate would be affected by the CO2 partial pressure, and when it increased, the formation rate of CO would get higher. While, for Route 2, the formation rate of CO was affected both by the surface coverage of adsorbed H and CO2. With higher CO2 partial pressure, the adsorbed CO2 would increase, while the adsorbed H would decrease due to the less CH4 amount, making the variation of CO formation rate to be unpredictable. By observing of experimental results, the step of CO formation might be determined by both routes simultaneously, because if the rate of CO formation was mainly determined by direct dissociation of CO2, the CO formation rate would increase gradually with the increase of partial pressure of CO2, but this was not the case. Several scholars [45,46] have reported that the activation energy of CO formation by HCOO species is approximately equal to the direct dissociation of CO2, meaning both of the routes (HCOO to CO and CO2 to CO) possess considerably contributiong to the formation of CO, which is in consistent with the present experimental reuslts. Furthermore, the increase in partial pressure of CO2 also affected the microsteps of H2 formation. In dark conditions, the formation rate and apparent activation energy of H2 were 113.9 kJ·g−1·mol−1 under CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1: 2, 116.2 kJ·g−1·mol−1 under CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.4: 2.4, and 121.6 kJ·g−1·mol−1 under CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.8: 2.8 respectively. Obviously, the increase of CO2 partial pressure could bring a decrease in H2 formation. This might be determined by the generation path of H2. In a typical DRM reaction, the generation of H2 mainly comes from the further combination of H dissociated from CH4. Therefore, the decrease of CH4 partial pressure slowed down the generation rate of adsorbed H species, which directly affected the formation rate of H2. Overall, in dark conditions, H species seems to be an important intermediate species in DRM reaction, which not only participates in H2 formation step, but also promotes CO generation through HCOO species. This means that the adsorption, activation and conversion of CH4 might mainly determine the DRM reaction process. Furthermore, the H2/CO ratio (0.59 at CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1: 2, 0.52 at CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.4: 2.4 and 0.48 at CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1.8: 2.8 under 500 °C) also decreased with the rising of CO2 partial pressure. This indicated that the combination of CO2 and H to generate HCOO and two adsorbed H to form H2 are a pair of competing reaction steps. When light irradiated on the catalyst surface, the variation tendency of H2 and CO formation rates were different from the dark conditions. For all the cases (with different feed gases molar ratios), DRM reaction would be proceeded with light irradiation, since the incident light would make more adsorbed species active, and lower the activation energy of the formation of H2 and CO. The activation energies for H2 and CO formation were lower at excess CO2 conditions compared with CH4: CO2: N2=1: 1: 2. In dark conditions, CH4 dissociation was considered as the RDS (rate determining step, RDS). Additionally, when irradiated by light, CH4 could be activated and converted more easily on the surface of catalyst. This might lead to the acceleration of H species generation, which could then promote both H2 and CO formation steps, thus increasing their formation rates and reducing the apparent activation energies. From Fig. 9(b), the apparent activation energies of H2 and CO were calculated by Arrhenius formula at 3.72 W·cm−2 with different feed gases molar ratio. Under the condition of CH4: CO2 = 1: 1.8, the apparent activation energy of the reaction decreased slightly compared with that of CH4: CO2 = 1: 1, but the decrease in value was not obvious. The reason might be that, although the activation degree of CH4 was improved under light conditions, which makes it easier to dissociate to generate H species, the low partial pressure of CH4 still led to a low formation rate of H species, so that making the formation of products only small difference compared with the dark condition. However, the lowest activation energies of H2 and CO were measured at CH4: CO2 = 1: 1.4, which means that increasing the partial pressure of CO2 moderately is beneficial to the reaction under light conditions. It was speculated that appropriately increasing the partial pressure of CO2 might lead to the consumption of H species, thus promoting the further dissociation of CH4 to generate the H species. The variations of formation rates and activation energies under different molar ratios also indicate that with low CO2/CH4, the RDS of DRM reaction may be CO formation step, while in high CO2/CH4 case, the RDS may transform to CH4 decomposition step. Another point should be noted that, under dark conditions, in the case of CH4: CO2=1:1 possesses the lowest activation energies for CO and H2 formation, and in the case of CH4: CO2=1:1.8 possesses the highest activation energies. While for the other two light irradiation cases (Fig. 11 ), the case of CH4: CO2=1:1.4 possesses the lowest activation energies, and in the case of CH4: CO2=1:1 possesses the highest activation energies for CO and H2 formation. The variation of activation energies with different molar ratios and light intensities also indicates the impact of different working conditions on the transformation of RDS and the reaction mechanism of photo-thermal catalytic DRM reaction. The H2/CO ratio was also affected by the specific working conditons. Generally, the H2 formation step is a quasi-2 order of adsorbed H species, and the formation of HCOO is 1 order of H. Therefore, high concentrations of H species might promote more direct synthesis of H2, and thereby increase the H2/CO ratio. So it could be found that the H2/CO ratio would decrease when CO2 partial pressure increases (Fig. 7(b)). In addition, Pt nanoparticles are regarded as the active center of CH4 dissociation. When irradiated by light, the SPR effect of Pt could result in a large increase in the concentration of H species [33]. So it could be observed that in all partial pressure, light irradiation could increase the H2/CO ratio (Fig. 7(b)). Besides, an increase in reaction temperature also leads to an enhancement of the catalyst's ability to dissociate CH4, thereby increasing the concentration of H species over the surface of the catalyst, and resulting in the promotion of H2 formation steps. 3.4 DRM reaction mechanism So far, the effects of reaction temperature, light intensity and molar ratio of feed gases on the kinetic characteristics of DRM have been discussed in detail. Based on the in-situ DRIFTs experimental results in our previously published work [33] and the results of this work, the mechanism of the DRM reaction is summarized in the following main steps and listed in Fig. 10, which includes: (1, 2) CH4 adsorbed and dissociated into CHx and H species; (3) CHx species further dissociated and generated H species; (4) H species combined to form H2; (5) CO2 adsorbed and reacted with surface H species to generate HCOO species; (6) CO2 adsorbed, activated and directly dissociated into CO and O species; (7) HCOO further produced CO; (8) Desorption of CO species. In dark conditions (Table 2 ), the increase of reaction temperature will undoubtedly accelerate the activation and dissociation process of CH4 and CO2 on the catalyst surface, which would increase the production rate of all intermediate species and all steps of product generation (1-8). It is worth noting that the temperature rise would be more favorable for the progress of steps 1, 2, and 4, that is, the dissociation of more CH4 leads to a higher concentration of H species, so that the step of H2 generation from H species (4) is more likely to occur. In addition, under dark conditions, decreasing the partial pressure of CH4 resulted in the slow-down of the H2 generation steps (1-4), making the dissociation of CH4 to be the RDS of the reaction. With the increase of CO2 partial pressure, the activation energy of H2 generation increases simutaneously. The decreased concentration of H species could also suppress step 5, but the CO2 formation rate is basically unchanged (500 °C) due to the acceleration of steps 6 and 8 caused by excess CO2 partial pressure. However, probably due to the difficulty in proceeding with step 6, the CO2 foramtion rate did not increase significantly. Therefore, under dark conditions, the CO2 generation step was controlled by steps 2 and 5-8 simultaneously. In light conditions (Table 3 ), at a given molar ratio of feed gases, the increase of incident light intensity also intensified all reaction steps, since the activation and transformation of the two reactants were both intensified by the SPR effect and photoexcited electrons and holes of the photo-thermal catalyst under light conditions, thus accelerate all the elementary steps. Besides, since CH4 dissociation could be enhanced significantly by incident lgiht, it would not be the RDS of the reaction under such condition. Therefore, when increasing CO2 partial pressure under light condition, the formation rates of H2 would be inceased. A moderate increase in CO2 partial pressure was beneficial to the further dissociation of CH4 to a certain extent, that is, it promoted the progress of step 5, thereby accelerating the production of H species in steps 2 and 3. However, too much CO2 (CO2:CH4=1.8:1) would lead to extremely low CH4 partial pressure, decreasing the total amount of dissociated H species, and thereby lowering the subsequent progress of H2 and intermediate HCOO formations. Different from H2, CO formation was related to two steps, decomposition of HCOO, and dissociation of CO2. The increasing of CO2 partial pressure would decrease the formation of HCOO, and increase the dissociation of CO2. Therefore, the variation of CO formation rate was determined by the relative competition between the two steps. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the performance of the highly active photo-thermal composite catalyst Pt/mesoporous-TiO2 was tested under different operating conditions, including reaction temperature (300 °C, 350 °C, 400 °C, 450 °C and 500 °C), light intensities (0 W·cm−2. 2.75 W·cm−2, 3.72 W·cm−2 and 4.67 W·cm−2) and molar ratio of feed gases (CH4: CO2: N2 = 1: 1: 2, CH4: CO2: N2 = 1: 1.4: 2.4 and CH4: CO2: N2 = 1: 1.8: 2.8). The effects of the above reaction conditions on the DRM reaction have been deeply studied and discussed. Among them, the higher of reaction temperature and light intensity would increase the generation rates of all intermediate species to improve the formation rates of the two products, in which the enhancement of the formation rate of H2 was more obvious. Besides, it is found that when reaction temperatures gets higher, the light intensification effect would get weaker, which has not been discussed by any other scholars. Regarding the effect of the inlet molar ratio on the reaction, the increase of CO2 partial pressure would slow down the step of H species generation under dark conditions, thereby reducing the H2 formation. Additionally, due to the difficulty of the direct dissociation step of CO2, the CO generation rate did not increase significantly. Under light conditions, a moderate increase of CO2 partial pressure can promote the dissociation of methane to a certain extent. The generated H species would simultaneously promote the production of HCOO species and H2, thereby increasing the formation rates of both products at the same time. In addition, a simple model of a possible light-enhanced reaction mechanism was proposed. With the proposed mode, the light-enhanced intensification ratios and value at different temperatures were systematically analyzed, and the contribution of light to the DRM reaction was discussed. The conclusions of the effect of reaction conditions on catalyst performance could be used for the subsequent catalyst design, development and photo-thermal chemical conversion process optimization. coredata.dc:description: Dry reforming of methane (DRM) reaction under photo-thermal catalysis route have attracted more and more attentions due to its fast reaction rate and higher conversion compared with traditional thermal catalysis techniques. However, most of current researches were mainly focused on the development of new photo-thermal catalysts, while the kinetic characteristics of DRM reaction under photo-thermal conditions was seldomly studied and discussed. Aiming this point, the performances of a Pt/mesoporous-TiO2 catalyst were investigated under different reaction conditions (reaction temperature, light irradiation intensity and molar ratio of feed gases) in this paper. It was found that (1) Increasing the light intensity and reaction temperature possessed a positive effect on the DRM reaction, increasing the formation rates of two products and H2/CO ratio; (2) The intensification ratio of formation rates of light/dark condition would decrease with higher reaction temperature; (3) Under dark conditions, increasing the partial pressure of CO2 was not conducive to the progress of the DRM reaction; (4) With light irradiation, an appropriate increase in the partial pressure of CO2 would be beneficial to the progress of the DRM reaction and improve the formation rates of the products. To explain the variations of light-enhanced intensification ratios and values at different temperatures, a possible simple model of light-enhanced reaction mechanism was proposed, and the contribution of light to the DRM reaction was deeply discussed. Meanwhile, combined with in situ DRIFTS characterization, the effects of operating conditions on specific micro-steps of the reaction were determined carefully. The obtained conclusions are of great practical significance for the design, development and process parameter optimization of photo-thermal DRM reaction process.
coredata.dc:title: Mechanism and kinetic characteristics of photo-thermal dry reforming of methane on Pt/mesoporous-TiO2 catalyst
